analyzeResult.content:
THE NATION ..
Reynolds to roll-out Camel 'magalog
Titled CML, magazine - being marketed solely through the maga- to be mailed to thousands Ezine. of smokers, 21 and older
THE NEW YORK TIMES
With Joe Camel gone, at the federal gov- ernment's insistence, R.J. Reynolds Tobac- .co Co. is turning to the magazine industry to give its biggest nondiscount brand 'a : boost.
The result is CME, a quarterly featuring what might be called the smoking lifestyle. Described by a Reynolds spokeswoman as a "magalog," as in magazine and catalog, the first issue includes articles on fashion, food, travel' and shopping, phuis what is billed as the first installment of a fiction serial that the magazine modestly charac- terizes as "the trashlest tale this side of Melrose Place ...
There are also ads for Camel cigarettes as well as for such accessories as ashtrays - and lighters - the better to smoke some- thing with its
So that Chut, which is being maled this month to hundreds of thousands of people . identified as smokers older than 21'in $0 . states, is not confused somehow with other lifestyle magazines, a quick look at the food section establishes where the CML target - audience is coming from.
The main article, "Cheat and Eat," tells . readers how to position themselves as chefs by-relying on packaged foods like Campbell's tomato soup, Stove Top stuff- . ing (made by Kraft, a division of Reynolds' rival, Philip Morris) and Jiffy corn-muffin · mix.
.. Then there are the articles about the bars of Miami's South Beach - not incidentally, all the ones that made the list participate in - Camel marketing programs - and biker : dudes at a festival in Sturgis, S.D., home of - the Camel Roadhouse, a bar declared "a „ focal point for the main action" in a picture " caption accompanying the article.
THE MAGAZINE BEGINS WITH "The CML Charter," in which the difference be- - tween Arabian and Bactrian camels are .. discussed. (The Camel-camel is an Arabi-
.. an.) The magazine moves on to describe itself as "informative, inspiring and above " all entertaining."
The widespread changes in the tobacco industry in the past year, including the settlement agreement that bans some kinds of cigarette marketing as well as steep price increases and more competition among brands, led to the decision to pro- duce CML, said Carole Crosslin, & spokes- woman for Reynolds.
eliminate the"guesswork in getting their message to the appropriate audience. With custom publishing, "content can be shaped directly by the advertiser,". said: David Wilkofsky, the managing partner of Wilkofsky Gruen Associates, a consulting firm.
"If an advertiser promotes his productk! on standard media, he can shape his mate ??
rounding his advertisement," he said. .It is hardly surprising, then, that there is nothing approaching a health-and-fitness tion in CML. Fire, smoke and cigarett i to be the dominant 'themes," ist a vaguely international, middle-in- come backdrop.
"A business profile zeroes in on Cengiz Emck, the general manager of a Turkish".
Philip Morris went into the magazine business in 1996 and now mails Unlimit- - tobacco. company. Turkey, the magazine" ed, published by Hachette Filipacchi, to? informs its readers, is "the smoker's para:" about 1.8 million households. disex' Al
The magazine, subtitled "Action, Adven" "ture and Good Times," is "not about smok- ing," said Michelle Berman, a vice presi dent and group publisher at the"custom! publishing division of Hachette Filipacchi, a subsidiary of Lagardere.
Unlimited has no articles about szok- ing and no photographs of people smok- ing, concentrating instead on outdoor ad- venture and other pursuits, Berman said.
"The only thing you'll see are Marlboro ads," she said. "It's going to customers who are 21- to 29-year-old smokers. This is really about their lifestyle."
In January, Brown & Williamson plans to mail The Art of Simple Living, which could also be subtitled Not About Smoking.
With such articles as "In Search of the Perfect Chocolate Chip Cookie" and "Starting School," and other features on pumpkin carving and household money
: As for Emek, "There is something almost" "shy about the way he explains that his job is" the culmination of a lifelong love affair with tobacco," the article says. "It started when By the smoked his first cigarette."
THE GLOBAL NEWS.PAGES of CML in- clude an article about Swissair's smoking' lounge in the Zurich airport and an update on the Montserrat volcano, which is appar- ently attracting tourists once again. Sam- "sonite's line of clothing also gets a men- tion, as does a new Chinese restaurant in" New York.
"The magazine is being produced by Wink Media in London, a unit of Time Warner: Tyler Brule, the creative director, is best known for Wallpaper, a home and lifestyle magazine that Time Warner acquired in 1997.
Unlike the Philip Morris magazine, CMC!
81638156
... It adds, "As well as this, you're unlikely : to track down a more inspiring source of exotic new blends from Camel than right. . co industry's. ._ here:"
The blends, which include vanilla-fla- ... vored and citrus-flavored cigarettes, are, rettes, all made by Brown & Williamson.
Like Real Edge and Flair, the magazine" is published by Hearst's custom-publishing division.
. Bill Pecoriello, a tobacco and beverage analys: for Sanford C. Bernstein, said that; as billboards and other channels for adver? tising had been closed off to tobacco com- panies, magazines became more attractive.
"You're going to see more of this type of,? direct communication with smokers," he ""We"need advertising vehicles to work " said. Custom publishing has surged theti ``` harder for us in this new world and to , past five years as advertisers seek ways to powerfully communicate our brand's posi- tioning to adult smokers," she said.
"CML will provide us with this opportu nity to reach adult smokers with our brand message."
OTHER TOBACCO COMPANIES have reached the same conclusion. Brown & Williamson; a unit of BAT Industries, begani publishing Real Edge late last year. The rial but he can't shape the content sur- magazine, focuses on men of a; certain mindset with articles on James Bond and extreme sports.
"Earlier this year, the company added Flair, which is almed at women and mod eled after, magazines like Glamour said. Steve Kottak, a spokesman for Brow Williamson.
management, the magazine's pilot issue. - has no advertising other than that placed
seems to draw more from Good House .. keeping's train of thought than the tobac-
A closer inspection turns up ads for Carl- ads from Reebok, Rite Aid and Subaru ton, Kool, Capri and Misty Lights ciga-
by Reynolds. Unlimited includes ads from Kawasaki, Jack Daniels, JVC Mobile and h the Franklin Mint, Berman said. Flair has
Real Edge Includes ads from Honda and Kawasaki.

THE NEW YORK TIMES

Then there are the articles about the bars of Miami's South Beach - not incidentally, all the ones that made the list participate in - Camel marketing programs - and biker : dudes at a festival in Sturgis, S.D., home of - the Camel Roadhouse, a bar declared "a „ focal point for the main action" in a picture " caption accompanying the article.

.. an.) The magazine moves on to describe itself as "informative, inspiring and above " all entertaining."

The widespread changes in the tobacco industry in the past year, including the settlement agreement that bans some kinds of cigarette marketing as well as steep price increases and more competition among brands, led to the decision to pro- duce CML, said Carole Crosslin, & spokes- woman for Reynolds.

eliminate the"guesswork in getting their message to the appropriate audience. With custom publishing, "content can be shaped directly by the advertiser,". said: David Wilkofsky, the managing partner of Wilkofsky Gruen Associates, a consulting firm.

rounding his advertisement," he said. .It is hardly surprising, then, that there is nothing approaching a health-and-fitness tion in CML. Fire, smoke and cigarett i to be the dominant 'themes," ist a vaguely international, middle-in- come backdrop.

Philip Morris went into the magazine business in 1996 and now mails Unlimit- - tobacco. company. Turkey, the magazine" ed, published by Hachette Filipacchi, to? informs its readers, is "the smoker's para:" about 1.8 million households. disex' Al

The magazine, subtitled "Action, Adven" "ture and Good Times," is "not about smok- ing," said Michelle Berman, a vice presi dent and group publisher at the"custom! publishing division of Hachette Filipacchi, a subsidiary of Lagardere.
Unlimited has no articles about szok- ing and no photographs of people smok- ing, concentrating instead on outdoor ad- venture and other pursuits, Berman said.
"The only thing you'll see are Marlboro ads," she said. "It's going to customers who are 21- to 29-year-old smokers. This is really about their lifestyle."
In January, Brown & Williamson plans to mail The Art of Simple Living, which could also be subtitled Not About Smoking.
With such articles as "In Search of the Perfect Chocolate Chip Cookie" and "Starting School," and other features on pumpkin carving and household money

: As for Emek, "There is something almost" "shy about the way he explains that his job is" the culmination of a lifelong love affair with tobacco," the article says. "It started when By the smoked his first cigarette."

THE GLOBAL NEWS.PAGES of CML in- clude an article about Swissair's smoking' lounge in the Zurich airport and an update on the Montserrat volcano, which is appar- ently attracting tourists once again. Sam- "sonite's line of clothing also gets a men- tion, as does a new Chinese restaurant in" New York.

"The magazine is being produced by Wink Media in London, a unit of Time Warner: Tyler Brule, the creative director, is best known for Wallpaper, a home and lifestyle magazine that Time Warner acquired in 1997.

Like Real Edge and Flair, the magazine" is published by Hearst's custom-publishing division.

. Bill Pecoriello, a tobacco and beverage analys: for Sanford C. Bernstein, said that; as billboards and other channels for adver? tising had been closed off to tobacco com- panies, magazines became more attractive.

Custom publishing has surged theti ``` harder for us in this new world and to , past five years as advertisers seek ways to powerfully communicate our brand's posi- tioning to adult smokers," she said.
"CML will provide us with this opportu nity to reach adult smokers with our brand message."
